questions.text: The most common ovarian tumour in individuals less than 20 years old is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In individuals less than 20 years of age, the most common ovarian tumours are of germ cell origin.


Explanation for other options:

Epithelial tumours (Option A): Rare in adolescents; more common after 30

Metastatic tumours (Option C): Uncommon in this age group

Sex cord stromal tumours (Option D): Less frequent than germ cell tumours

questions.text: Ovarian tumours commonly arise from:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most common origin of ovarian tumours is from the surface (germinal) epithelium of the ovary. In general, epithelial tumours comprise 50-60% of all ovarian tumours.

  • The surface (germinal) epithelium refers to the mesothelial lining of the ovary, not the true germ cells.
  • Though the name includes "germinal," it refers to the epithelial origin.

choices.text: Accounts for 20% of all ovarian tumours
Common in the postmenopausal age group

questions.text: True about Brenner tumour:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Brenner tumour (Transitional cell tumour) is common in the postmenopausal age group.

  • Origin: Surface (transitional-cell) epithelial tumour
  • It is a rare epithelial neoplasm of the ovary resembling a fibroma.
  • Behaviour: > 90 % are benign; malignant transformation is rare
  • Causes menopausal bleeding and Pseudomeig syndrome (ascites and hydrothorax).
  • Malignant change is very rare.
  • Histologically, it shows walthard cell rests of transitional cells, cells have coffee bean nuclei, cut section is gritty.
  • Association: May coexist with other epithelial tumours (e.g., mucinous cystadenoma)

Explanation for other options:

Usually bilateral (Option A): Brenner tumours are typically unilateral.

Resembles serous cystadenoma (Option B): Histologically, Brenner tumours have transitional (urothelial-type) epithelium in dense fibrous stroma, not similar to serous tumours.

Accounts for 20% of all ovarian tumours (Option C): They are rare, comprising <2% of ovarian tumours.

questions.text: Which of the following are masculinising tumours of the ovary?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Masculinising tumours develop from the Sex cord of the Embryonic gonad and include

  • Arrhenoblastoma/Androblastoma Hilus cell Tm
  • Adrenal cortical Tm/Lipoid cell Tm of the ovary
  • Gynandroblastoma

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding granulosa cell tumour of the ovary?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Granulosa cell tumour of the ovary is associated with the Ca endometrium.

Granulosa cell tumour is a sex cord tumour.

  • Age: Most common before puberty and after 40 years. (Option A ruled out)
  • Tumour secretes estrogen, which is responsible for clinical features like precocious puberty, menometrorrhagia and post menopausal bleeding.
  • They are low-grade malignancies.
  • Almost always unilateral (Option D ruled out)

Malignant transformation:

  • Associated with Endometrial hyperplasia and malignancies. (Option C ruled out)
  • 5 per cent of tumours are associated with endometrial cancer.

Marker: Granulosa cell tumours secrete inhibin, which is a useful marker for it.

Prognosis is good, with a 5-year survival rate being 90%.

Metastasis: It is peculiar in the case of granulosa cell tumour, it first involves the opposite ovary, followed by metastasis in the lumbar region.

questions.text: The most common pure germ cell tumour of the ovary:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most common pure germ cell tumour of the ovary is dysgerminoma.

Germ cell tumours of the ovary:

In contrast to slow-growing epithelial ovarian tumours, germ cell malignancies grow rapidly and are characterised by subacute pelvic pain.

  • The most common germ cell tumour is mature teratoma or Dermoid cyst(Benign in nature).
  • The second most common malignant GCT is immature cystic teratoma

questions.text: False about dermoid cyst of the ovary:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Dermoid cyst of the ovary does not invariably turn to malignancy

Dermoid cyst: A Dermoid cyst is a benign teratoma.

  • It is the most common benign tumour of the ovary in the reproductive age group.
  • The most common benign neoplasm diagnosed during pregnancy.The most common Germ cell tumour.
  • It is the commonest tumour to undergo torsion.
  • Characteristically, they are unilocular cysts containing hair and cheesy sebaceous material, teeth, bones, thyroid tissue and cartilage.
  • If teeth or bone are seen in an X-ray in an adnexal mass, this finding is pathognomic for teratoma, and thus X-ray is diagnostic.
  • Malignant change in a dermoid cyst is extremely rare; if it develops, it is squamous cell carcinoma.

choices.text: Associated with ascites and pleural effusion

questions.text: True about Meigs syndrome:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Meigs syndrome is associated with ascites and pleural effusion

Meigs Syndrome

Triad: Ascites + Right-sided pleural effusion (hydrothorax) + Benign solid ovarian tumour

Most commonly associated with:

  • Fibroma
  • Thecoma
  • Fibrothecoma
  • Brenner tumour(Brenner is part of true Meigs, not pseudo-Meigs)

Key features:

  • Spontaneous resolution of ascites and hydrothorax after tumour removal
  • Rare: Occurs in <5% of fibromas
  • Ascites typically occurs when the tumour is>6 cm

Pseudo-Meigs Syndrome

Same clinical picture as Meigs (ascites + hydrothorax)

But associated with:

  • Other ovarian tumours(benign or malignant)
  • Sometimes due to metastasis or hormonal stimulation (e.g., gonadotropin-induced ovarian enlargement)
  • Does not meet Meigs' criteria because the tumour is not a benign solid tumour like a fibroma or Brenner

Key Takeaway:

  • Meigs = Fibroma/Thecoma/Fibrothecoma/Brenner + ascites + hydrothorax
  • Pseudo-Meigs = Other tumours (e.g., malignant/mucinous) + ascites + hydrothorax
  • Both resolve post-tumour removal, but only Meigs' meets strict diagnostic criteria.

Reference: Meigs Syndrome - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

questions.text: Meigs syndrome is associated with:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Meigs syndrome is associated with ovarian fibroma.

questions.text: The most common complication of an ovarian tumour is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Torsion is the most common complication of an ovarian tumour.

Complications of Ovarian tumour (TRIP):

T (Torsion)

  • Most common complication
  • Seen in 12% cases
  • Most common in benign tumours
  • The most common tumour to undergo torsion is the dermoid cyst.

R (Rupture)

  • Which can be traumatic or spontaneous.

I (Infection)

  • Rare complication
  • Seen following acute salpingitis or during puerperium as a part of an ascending genital tract infection.

P (Pseudomyxoma peritonei)

  • The peritoneal cavity is filled with coagulated mucinous material.
  • Most common in mucinous cystadenoma and mucinous carcinoma.

Also seen in: Mucocele of the appendix, Carcinoma appendix, and Carcinoma of the large intestine.

questions.text: Most common ovarian cyst to undergo torsion:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A benign cystic teratoma is the most common neoplasm to undergo torsion, and it is the most common benign tumour diagnosed during pregnancy.

  • A benign cystic teratoma is synonymous with dermoid cyst/mature teratoma.
  • They are commonin reproductive-age women
  • They are usually unilateral, mobile, and have a moderate size
  • These features increase their risk of torsion

Explanation for other options:

Dysgerminoma (Option B): It rarely undergoes torsion. This is because it is typically a solid and large tumour, often bilateral, which reduces its mobility within the pelvis.

Ovarian fibroma (Option C): It has a low risk of torsion. It is a firm, solid, and relatively immobile tumour, more commonly associated with Meigs syndrome than with torsion.

Brenner’s tumour (Option D): It also seldom undergoes torsion. It is usually small, solid, and well-encapsulated, which makes it less likely to twist on its pedicle.

questions.text: The pseudomyxoma peritonei occurs as a complication of the following ovarian tumours:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The pseudomyxoma peritonei occurs as a complication of mucinous cystadenoma

Pseudomyxoma peritonei is a condition in which the neoplastic epithelium secretes large amounts of gelatinous mucinous material.

It is most commonly seen secondary to:

  • Appendicular carcinoma (well-differentiated carcinoma).
  • Ovarian mucinous carcinoma; mucinous cystadenoma.
  • Mucocele of the appendix (less commonly seen).

Even after the removal of the ovarian tumours, these cells continue to secrete mucin.

Tendency of recurrence is present, and the prognosis is poor.

Management:

  • Hysterectomy with BSO with removal of mucin peritoneal implants, along with the appendix

questions.text: Attacks of flushing and cyanosis occur in which type of ovarian tumours?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Attacks of flushing and cyanosis occur in carcinoid tumours of the ovary.

Carcinoid tumour of the ovary:

  • It is sometimes primary and sometimes metastatic.
  • Also called Argentaffinoma.
  • Occurs as a malignant change in a benign dermoid cyst.
  • Due to the secretion of serotonin and histamine-like substances, attacks of flushing and cyanosis are caused.

Carcinoid Syndrome:

  • Flushing
  • Cyanosis
  • Diarrhoea
  • Wheezing / Bronchospasm
  • Right-sided heart lesions

This syndrome occurs without liver metastasis in ovarian carcinoid tumours because hormones bypass hepatic metabolism (unlike GI carcinoid tumours).

Explanation for other options:

Struma ovarii (Option A): Produces thyroid hormones, which may cause thyrotoxicosis, not flushing/cyanosis.

Krukenberg tumour (Option B): Metastatic gastric cancer to the ovary with no hormonal symptoms.

Arrhenoblastoma (Sertoli-Leydig cell tumour) (Option C): Produces androgens and leads to virilisation, not carcinoid features.

questions.text: A lady has an ovarian mass, X-ray pelvis shows a radio-opaque shadow. The probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

An ovarian mass with a radio-opaque shadow on X-ray points towards the dermoid cyst as the diagnosis.

Causes of Pelvic Calcification are:

  • Fibroids: popcorn type
  • Dermoid cyst: It is the commonest ovarian mass to calcify
  • Other ovarian masses: cystadenoma/carcinoma, fibromas
  • Pseudomyxoma peritonei
  • Fallopian tube calcification (rare): suggests TB
  • Uterine, i.e. endometrial calcification from chronic endometritis.

questions.text: Marker for granulosa cell tumour:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most specific marker for granulosa cell tumour is Inhibin (especially Inhibin B).

  • Anti-Müllerian Hormone (AMH) may also be elevated and used for follow-up.

choices.text: Only follow up without surgical intervention
Cesarean delivery and ovariotomy at term

questions.text: A 15 cm X 15 cm ovarian cyst has been diagnosed in an 8-week pregnant lady. Further Management includes:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

For a 15 cm X 15 cm ovarian cyst in the 8th week of pregnancy, laparotomy at 14-16 weeks (2nd trimester) is preferred management.

Ovarian cysts in pregnancy

  • Dysgerminomas are the most common malignant tumour diagnosed during pregnancy, but overall most common is dermoid cyst.
  • The most common ovarian cyst diagnosed in pregnancy is a dermoid cyst
  • The most common ovarian tumour to undergo torsion in pregnancy is a dermoid cyst
  • The most common time for an ovarian cyst to undergo torsion in pregnancy is the end of the first trimester and/or puerperium.

Key Points:

  • Imaging (USG/MRI) is crucial for cysts between 5-10 cm.
  • Surgery, if needed, is ideally planned in the second trimester (14–20 weeks)to reduce risk to both mother and fetus.
  • In cases of emergency (e.g., torsion, rupture), surgery is preferred, irrespective of size and weeks of gestation.

questions.text: Lutein cysts are associated with all except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

OCPs (Oral Contraceptive Pills) suppress ovulation and hence prevent the development of functional cysts like lutein cysts. So, there is no direct association with their use.

  • Lutein cysts(especially theca lutein cysts) are functional ovarian cysts that develop due to excessive stimulation by hCG.
  • They are typically bilateral and multiloculated and resolve spontaneously after the hCG levels decline. (Option C)

Associated With:

  • Gestational trophoblastic disease (e.g., hydatidiform mole, choriocarcinoma) is associated with lutein cysts due to excess hCG. (Option A)
  • Clomiphene citrate is used in ovulation induction; it causes overstimulation of the ovaries. (Option A)
  • Multiple gestation pregnancies cause higher hCG levels.
  • Fertility treatments cause increased gonadotropin stimulation.
  • Hyperemesis gravidarum is also linked with high hCG.

Spontaneous regression is expected within a few weeks following effective therapy of the tumours, with the gonadotropin level returning to normal.

questions.text: Which is most commonly implicated in genital(vulval) warts?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

HPV 6 is most commonly implicated in genital(vulval) warts among the given options.

Genital Warts:

  • Genital warts are lesions caused by productive infection with HPV (types 6 and 11 cause nearly all genital warts).
  • They display various morphologies and appearances ranging from flat papules to the classic verrucous, polyphytic lesions, termed "condyloma acuminata".

Sites:

  • Lower reproductive tract
  • Urethra
  • Anus
  • Mouth

Diagnosis:

  • Diagnosed by clinical infection,
  • Biopsy is not required unless co-existing neoplasia is suspected.
  • HPV serotyping is not required for routine diagnosis.

Treatment:

  • Condyloma acuminata may remain unchanged or resolve spontaneously.
  • Lesions can be destroyed with sharp or electrosurgical excision, cryotherapy, or laser ablation.
  • Very large, bulky lesions may be managed with cavitational ultrasonic surgical aspiration.
  • Treatment should be selected based on clinical circumstances and patient and provider preferences.
  • Intralesional injection of interferon (costly, painful and inconvenient to administer).

questions.text: All of these secrete hormones, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Dysgerminoma is a tumour which is neutral and does not secrete either male or female sex hormones, but secretes placental alkaline phosphatase, lactate dehydrogenase and beta hCG.

choices.text: Squamous intraepithelial cells associated with HPV 16
Squamous intraepithelial neoplasia associated with HIV

questions.text: Patient diagnosed as squamous cell intraepithelial lesion, which of the following has the highest risk for progression to carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

HSIL (High-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion) has the highest potential to progress to cervical carcinoma compared to all other listed conditions.

Classification Systems:

WHO Classification:

  • CIN I: Mild dysplasia
  • CIN II: Moderate dysplasia
  • CIN III: Severe dysplasia to carcinoma in situ

Bethesda System:

  • LSIL (Low-grade SIL): CIN I
  • HSIL (High-grade SIL): CIN II + CIN III

Risk of Progression to Carcinoma:

  • HSIL carries the highest risk of progression to invasive cervical cancer.
  • HSIL includes CIN II, CIN III, and Carcinoma in situ.
  • The chance of CIN III progressing to cancer is significantly higher than LSIL.

Explanation for other options:

LSIL (CIN I) (Option A): Often regresses spontaneously, especially in younger women.

HPV 16 association (Option C): Increases risk, but by itself does not determine grade.

HIV association (Option D): Can increase persistence/progression of lesions, but HSIL itself carries the highest risk.

questions.text: All are premalignant lesions of the vulva except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Leukoplakia is a clinical term for white patches on the mucosa. It can be associated with premalignant conditions but is not inherently premalignant on its own.

Precancerous and non-neoplastic lesions of the vulva with the potential to progress to carcinoma:

questions.text: Treatment of intraepithelial Paget's disease
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Local excision is the treatment of choice for Paget's disease, providing histology and margin control.

  • Paget's Disease of the Vulvais mostly confined to the epithelium.
  • It occurs in two forms:Intraepithelial Paget's disease and Invasive Paget's disease
  • It is most common in postmenopausal women
  • Patients complain of itching, irritation and bleeding
  • The lesion has slightly raised margins, is erythematous, with islands of white epithelium.
  • Histologically, it is characterised by Paget cells, Velvety red lesions
  • 10-15% patients with vulvar Paget's disease have an underlying adenocarcinoma of sweat glands
  • 10% of patients with vulvar Paget's disease also have associated breast, colon or genitourinary cancer.
  • Workup of Paget's disease should include colonoscopy, cystoscopy, mammography and colposcopy.

Treatment

  • Intraepithelial Paget managed with wide local excision
  • Invasive Paget's managed with radical vulvectomy with lymph node dissection

questions.text: All are benign lesions of vagina except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Vaginal intraepithelial neoplasia is not a benign lesions of vagina. It is defined as squamous cell dysplasia, including maturation abnormalities and cytopathic changes, which do not extend beyond the basement membrane, also premalignant.

Benign lesions of vagina:

  • Congenital malformations (Option A)
  • Infections (Option B)
  • Ulcers (Option C)
  • Scarring
  • Stenosis
  • DES-induced lesions
  • Granulation tissue
  • Cysts

questions.text: Common site for gartner duct cyst of vagina
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Gartner duct cyst is a remnant of the mesonephric (Wolffian) duct which are typically found in the anterior and lateral wall of the upper vagina.

  • Paramesonephric ducts or Mullerian ducts form female genital organs, whereas mesonephric ducts form male genital organs.
  • The remnant of the mesonephric duct or Wolffian duct in females sometimes forms a mesonephric cyst, or a Gartner's duct cyst.
  • They are non-malignant
  • They are usually asymptomatic and <2 cm, but sometimes can be bigger.
  • It is diagnosed with a pelvic examination. Seen in the anterior and lateral wall of vagina in the lower part.
  • It is treated with surgical excision of the cyst.
